You can duplicate these fun edges for your next project. Just increases and decreases, throw in a few eyelets and you may come up with a unique design of your own.

title: Knitting a 1-Piece Bolster Pillow
description:
Knitting this one-piece bolster pillow can be as easy or as complicated as you like.
Work short row shaping for the ends, kitchener stitch one long seam ... voila! A pretty gift or addition to your room.

title: Knitweave Without Brushes
description:
If your knitting machine doesn't have weaving brushes, you can still work knitweave.

You can achieve the same results by manually weaving the decorative yarn over and under needles instead of relying on brushes.

title: Automatic Wraps for a Godet (Triangle Shape)
description: Automatic shaping is a method of partial knitting (short rows) that many knitters prefer. Watch as we prevent short row holes "automatically".pattern by Anne Lavene "Patrixbourne"

title: Lifelines: A Knitter's Best Friend
description:
How many times have you tirelessly worked on a technique or a large section of knitting, then had disaster strike and you had to start all over?

This has happened to us all!

Lifelines to the rescue! This tutorial covers 2 methods of rescuing your work from disaster.

title: Designer I-Cord Seams and Edges
description: Add designer details to your garments with basic I-Cord accented seams and garment edges.

title: Multiple Waves
description:
This is a hand-manipulated, lacy, openwork technique that can be done on any knitting machine, with any yarn. No punchcards or programming.

It's reversible, making it a great choice for scarves or shawls.

Watch as we work the partial knitting that makes this so beautiful!

title: Raglan Seam Options
description:
There are many, many ways to add a decorative touch to raglan decrease seams.

Make the seams the focal point of your sweater. Here are a few suggestions.

Simple 1 stitch decrease, Transfer Decreases, Machine Seams, i-Cord seams and more!

title: More Elongated Stitches
description:
Worked on any machine, this openwork stitch pattern has many possibilities. Work large stitches by themselves or combine with other manual or automatic stitch patterns for unique designs.
Great for scarves, shawls and sweaters.

title: Fairisle: What Knitting Machines Do Best
description: Sometimes machine knitters over complicate things ... get back to basics and practice the built-in capabilities of your machine. Painless, stranded knitting, 2 color knitting, fairisle.

title: Knitter's Math Tools - Rectangles and Squares
description:
Create your own scarves, shawls, pillows, and blankets. Use any yarn, any machine and any stitch gauge.

Let us do the math for you and generate your own custom knitting patterns based on YOUR gauge.

title: Yarn Estimator
description:
Determine if you have enough yarn to finish your project. A swatch, a scale and a few measurements and you'll never worry about running out again!
Knit it Now Yarn Estimator tool

title: Mock Ribbing Variations
description:
No ribber? Don't hand knit, but want ribbing?

Many machine knitters turn to mock ribbing for the hems and cuffs of their sweaters.

Here are 3 needle arrangements that are surprisingly pretty that will give you the ribbed look you want.

title: Corrugated Rib on the Machine
description:
Hand knitters work a 2 color ribbing that they call corrugated rib.

The knit stitches are worked in color A and the purl stitches are worked in color B.

Machine knitters can imitate this technique using our ribbers and a bit of hand maniupulation.
No ribber? Try Mock Corrugated Ribbing

title: Mock Corrugated Ribbing
description:
In a previous video we explored creating corrugated rib on the knitting machine. This involved using a ribber and some hand manipulation to have knit stitches and purl stitches in alternating colors.

You can create a similar look without a ribber. Included is a "mini hung hem" technique that can be used often.

title: Color Block Cables
description: Combining blocks of color with cables is a great way to add interest to your designs. Use for sleeves, yokes, pillows, blankets ... get creative!

title: Blister Stitch Tips
description:
This is a "basic" knitting stitch, with practically unlimited variations. It is also known as Coin Stitch, Bubbles, Bricks, Blocks.
Here are tips for success in working this stitch on the machine.

We are thinking hats, mittens, pillows ... how about you?

title: Drop Stitch Rib
description:
Here is a pretty, openwork stitch pattern that isn't as hard as it looks.

Knit a fairly basic 3x2 rib, but drop a few stitches here and there .... VOILA!

If you have a basic understanding of your ribber and and you are able to knit ribbing you can knit this stitch pattern. Understanding racking for the needle setup makes things easier, too.

Try it! You will love it!

title: DAK 8 - Motif Placement
description:
Position a large motif on a square pillow cover. Practice using DAK tools in a practical application.
In Original Pattern drafting, create size and manipulate an original piece
In Stitch Designer, place and center a single motif on your piece. Manipulate the colors and print a diagram for hand manipulation or hand knitting.

The skills covered can be applied to garment design - practice using the basic tools and apply them to future projects.

title: No Fuss, Upside-Down, Hung Hem
description: Inspired by a ready-to-wear sweater, this hem adds an interesting small roll a the hem join.

title: Hybrid Intarsia - Method 1
description:
Knit multiple colors in a row without an intarsia carriage. Combine hand manipulated stitches and the speed of the knitting machine to create beautiful designs.
Hybrid Intarsia - method 2

title: Hybrid Intarsia - Method 2
description:
For machines without an intarsia carriage, use the hold setting to knit more than 1 color across a row with minimal or no floats.
Hybrid Intarsia - method 1

title: Bonnie's One Piece Cocoon Pattern
description:
Here's an interesting, comfortable and fashionable shape that is perfect for knitting on the machine.
With a bit of shaping, pleats and strategic folds, take a simple rectangle and make a beautifully draped garment.

With the Knit it Now Dynamic pattern, you can use any yarn, any machine and any stitch pattern. Make it your own!
Dynamic Pattern
Start-to-Finish Home Study Course

title: Open and Close Latches Manually
description: Here are some time-saving tips that I often use without thinking.

title: Picot and Eyelet Hem
description: Simple, lacy, hung hem with eyelets. Useful when knitting an openwork pattern. Decorative on plain knitting.

title: Scalloped Eyelet Hem
description:
Delicate scalloped hem. 3 variations with eyelets for a beautiful beginning.

Afterthought scallops

Scalloped Edge

title: Best Ever Picot Hem
description:
Here is a great picot hem that is less bulky and more feminine than any other!

There is a little more transferring to do, but the results are well worth it!

title: Scalloped Edge
description:
Pretty, scalloped, firm edge that resists the dreaded stockinette curl.
This tutorial covers scalloped hems and bands, walking you through the entire process from cast on to finishing touches

title: Double Bed Pintucks
description:
A nice edge on cuffs or the bottom of a jacket. Knitting full needle rib pintucks is a snap! One carriage setting and you can add texture and interest to your garments.

NOTE: This video demonstrates pintucks that are formed by using slip stitch on the ribber. the same effect can be worked with by slipping on the main bed.

Pintucks form when stitches are knit on one bed and corresponding stitches are slipped on the opposite bed.

title: Fence Post Hem (Double Bed)
description: Firm, decorative hem using the ribber. Includes printable worksheet.

title: Flat Picot Hem
description: A basic picot hem that lays flat because of using every other needle on the private side. Picots without transferring stitches!  A staple hem for every knitter.

title: Afterthought Scallop
description:
Added to the side of a knitted piece, this edge provides a firm base for a soft scallop. Perfect for the front opening of a cardigan.

Eliminate the scallops for an "all purpose" edge that mimics a garter stitch band

title: Elongated Stitches (no ribber)
description:
Easy open work stitch pattern that produces a light and airy fabric. Beautiful on both sides, it can be used for scarves, shawls or inserts.

Employ the ribber for this technique. Elongated Stitches ( ribber)

title: Elongated Stitches (double bed)
description:
Easy open work stitch pattern that produces a light and airy fabric. Beautiful on both sides, it can be used for scarves, shawls or inserts.

Using the ribber makes the knitting very quick.

Create this beautiful lace without a ribber. Elongated Stitches (no ribber)

title: Weaving Cast on
description:
A quick and easy method to start knitting. Useful for swatches and scrap and ravel cast on. Your machine must have weaving brushes.
No brushes? Check out "Weaving Cast on Without Brushes"

title: Full Fashioned Decreases
description:
Full fashioned decreases leave a smooth edge on your knitted pieces, making seaming easier. Shown are 2 methods you will use.
2 minutes

title: Hung Hem Basics
description:
The classic hung hem is the basis for many decorative hems that you will use. Use this technique for bands as well.

This tutorial includes 3 methods of creating the perfect hem

title: Short Row Increases and Decreases
description: Using short rows to increase or decrease stitches for curved edges or tapers.

title: Creating a Cast on Rag
description:
A cast on rag is very useful when you need to cast on stitches. It can be used in place of scrap yarn in any situation, but it is especially useful when casting on stitches in the middle of a piece.

This tutorial covers 3 types of cast on rags, including crochet as well as suggestions for using them.

Thanks for the idea of a crocheted cast on rag. The knitted ones always curl and ruffle for me. Double crochet seems best; my claw weights get a grip without a struggle. - Meg

title: 3- Needle Bind off (Shoulder Seams)
description:
Joining shoulders seams on the machine creates a tidy seam and stabilizes the garment shoulders.
This is the machine knitting version of the hand knitting 3-needle bind off.

title: Chain Cast On
description:
A staple for every machine knitter, this cast on will match a stitch through stitch bind off. Good for blankets and scarves
Suggested Videos: Creating a Cast on Rag
Chain Cast On with Scrap and Ravel

title: E-Wrap Cast On
description: A quick and easy basic cast on. A need-to-know for every machine knitter.

title: Crochet Buttons
description: Have perfectly matched buttons by crocheting them from your garment yarn. Fast and easy, they add a fun touch ... especially for kids!

title: One Piece Neckband Perfection
description:
There are many methods for finishing necklines. Here are 2 band techniques that can be used for shaped or cut 'n sew necklines.
Add a professional finish to your next project.
01:10 refers to this video:
https://www.knititnow.com/learn/tutorial/387/calculating-bands

title: Show Off Seams 2
description:
Improve seams done when knitting in pattern. Tuck, slip, fairisle ... add a professional finish to your work.
For more show-off seams see Show off Seams

title: Intarsia Carriage
description:
The ability to knit multiple colors across a row without long floats make intarsia a very versatile technique.
Some knitting machines have built in intarsia capabilities, but most require an intarsia carriage accessory.
Watch as we explore the intarsia carriage.

NOTE: The intarsia ebook that is mentioned in the video is no longer available.

title: Fine Knit Bar - Close Knit Bar
description:
The Fine Knit Bar (or Close Knit Bar) is an accessory that came with some knitting machine ribbers.
It's occasionally used when knitting certain stitch patterns and fine yarns.
Let's look at 2 different styles (Brother and Silver).

title: Fine Lace on Brother Machines
description:
Fine Lace is a technique that is available with the Brother standard gauge machines with a lace carriage.

Fine Lace provides fabulous texture. It can be combined with Normal Lace (with eyelets) for wonderful stitch patterns. Depending on your yarn choice, you can get very different results with the same Fine Lace pattern.

title: Replacing a Sponge Bar
description:
The Needle Retaining Bar (also known as a Sponge Bar or Sponge Presser Bar) on a knitting machine holds the needles in place.  Most metal bed machines have a retaining bar.  
A deteriorated or flattened bar is the cause of many problems that new knitters experience.
Replacing the Sponge Bar is simple and should be done regularly.

title: Color Block Pillow
description: Color blocks can be added to any knitted project.  Here are some suggestions for success.

title: Restore Rusty Needles
description: Pristine machine ... rusty needles ... a little elbow grease and voila!  Ready to knit!

title: Linen Stitch on the Knitting Machine
description:
Linen stitch is a beautiful way to add texture to your knitting. For hand knitters, there are many variations on this ever-popular stitch pattern.

Machine knitters can knit a simple every other needle slip stitch and use the purl side as the right side, but we can also duplicate the look of linen stitch on the knit side of the work.

Here are 2 techniques to try ... get stitching!

title: Lifted Lace
description:
Here's a beautiful lace that can be worked on any machine. A little hand manipulation does the trick for a loose, open fabric.

If you don't have a lace carriage, the possibilities of this technique are endless.

title: Top Down Set In Sleeves
description:
The idea of knitting a set in sleeve from the top down is appealing. Many knitters don't like to set in sleeves.
It's possible to re-hang the armhole edge on the machine and knit and join your sleeve cap using short row knitting.
Let's investigate this technique and compare it to the traditional method of knitting a separate sleeve and setting it into the armhole by hand.

title: Square Neck Mitered Band
description:
Decorative mitered bands add a beautiful finishing touch for a square neckline. Using decreases and short rows, this technique takes a bit of time, but is worth the effort!
Part 2

title: Square Neck Mitered Band 2
description:
After shaping the public side of the band, use short rows to shape a facing for your one-piece square neckline band.
Part 1

title: Retro Patterns ... reborn!
description:
Take a "vintage" design and make it your own! Use the Knit it Now Retro Patterns with any knitting machine and any yarn. These are updated, easy to follow instructions, wide range of sizes in classic styles.
Don't be limited to a specific gauge. Don't be intimidated by all those abbreviations.
Use your favorite machine, stitch pattern and yarn and make it your own!

title: Tuck Lace
description:
Want open texture without stitch transfers or a lace carriage? Think Tuck Lace!
Want a beautiful all-over texture on any machine? Think Tuck Lace!
Combine tuck with needles out of work and the possibilities are endless.

title: Zippers in Knitting
description:
I've never understood why some knitters freak out if you use the words zipper and knitting in the same sentence.

Adding a zipper to a garment isn't hard and there is no reason to be afraid to try.

Watch as we "just do it!"

title: Garter Stitch - RTR
description: RTR (Remove, Turn, Rehang) is a technique that reverses the knit and purl stitches on the machine. It can be used to create turning rows, or decorative garter rows. In this tutorial we'll use a hand knitting needle to RTR.  Just right for a quick turn for your knitting.

title: Sew-as-you-go Tricks
description:
Getting neat joins when working sew-as-you-go can be challenging... especially when using the standard gauge machine.

Here are 2 tricks that will help you create perfect seams, every time!

title: Free Pass (Position the carriage)
description:
You just ripped out a row of knitting, or put some knitting back on the bed from waste yarn or the garter bar. Perhaps you did a bit of shaping and now your carriage is on the opposite side of the working yarn.

Positioning the carriage is an essential skill for machine knitters. Here are 3 things you can do....

title: Lacy Waves
description:
Interesting, textured, openwork stitch pattern that can be worked on any knitting machine. It is worked with a bridging technique and short rows.
You may know this pattern as "Worm Lace"

title: Cable Eyelet Ribbing
description:
Adapted from a hand knitting pattern, this is a beautiful combination of knit and purl stitches, eyelets and cables.

2 methods are demonstrated, one stretchy and a perfect substitute for plain old ribbing. The other has no stretch, better for an all over fabric design or an insert.

If you don't have a ribber, with a little extra hand manipulation you can still work this interesting stitch pattern.

title: Carriage Lock
description:
Here's a nifty little piece that you may have .... but not use. It's called a carriage lock.
As the name implies, it's used when you are packing your machine to keep the carriage secure.
The different brands and models of machines have different styles ... let's take a look.

title: Yoga Socks - Watch and Learn
description:
Watch as we knit our Yoga Socks
Subscribers: Look for the Yoga Sock Quick WinMore tutorials, tips and inspiration

title: Pick up a Dropped Stitch
description: If a stitch drops, don't panic! Use a single transfer tool to neatly pickup the stitch and re-hang it on the machine.

title: Make Hand Manipulation Easier
description:
Make it easier to select needles for hand manipulation with Knit it Now Cheat Sheets.
Download a copy for your gauge machine

title: Mock Ribbing How To
description:
Mock Ribbing (False Ribbing) is a good substitute for hand knitting ribbing, hand manipulating ribbing or using a ribber.
Learn the basic technique (with a few tips thrown in)

title: Closed Cast on Methods
description: 3 popular Closed Cast on Methods

title: Fast 'n Easy Cast On
description: 3 quick closed cast on methods

title: Vertical Buttonholes
description: A vertical buttonholes to bands and collars.  Shown in Full Needle Rib, this technique can be used with most any stitch pattern, both single and double bed.

title: Peek inside a Designer Sweater
description: Here's a rare opportunity to peek at the finishing techniques of Eileen Montgomery.

title: Spacing Button Holes (no math)
description: Here's a "no math" way to position buttonholes on a horizontal band. When you pick up and knit a band, quickly determine where to work your buttonholes with minimal fuss.

title: Small Scallops (Double Bed)
description: Delicate scallops with transferred stitches

title: Rescue Row
description:
Prevent dropped stitches and disaster!
You've ripped out a row or rehung stitches and now the stitches on the needlebed are behind the latches and not in the hooks. If your next step is to transfer stitches or do some hand manipulation, you may find it difficult.
Use this tip to "clean up" the needlebed and prepare the needles and stitches for the hand manipulation.

title: Crochet-Look Neckline and Hem Trim on the Machine
description:
Here is an absolutely gorgeous edge that looks like crochet, but easily worked on the machine.
Once you see the basic construction, I'm sure you'll come up with lots of variations of your own.
This edge can be worked as a hem, along the side of a knitted piece, (like a cardigan front) or even used as a neckband.

title: Interrupted Patterning Part 2
description:
Continuing a detailed demonstration of stopping and re-starting stitch patterning.

Part 1 Part 3

title: Interrupted Patterning Part 1
description:
Shaping garments while working with automatic stitch patterns can be one of the more challenging tasks for a machine knitter.
An understanding of YOUR machine, it's settings and patterning device is essential.
This tutorial is designed for those who are comfortable with automatic stitch patterning and are ready to take the next step ... shaping.

Part 2 Part 3

title: Using the Pet Vest Pattern
description:
This custom pattern allows you to create a vest for your pet. Enter the dimensions and your gauge and you'll have a custom pattern. Use any yarn, stitch pattern and machine ... No Math!
Pet Vest for Larger Dogs

title: Dowagers Hump Adjustment
description:
As we age, our bodies change. The shoulders and head tilt forward.
Our favorite sweaters and blouses seem to creep up in the back. The issue is that there isn't enough length to from the center back neck to the hem.
If YOU need more length in the back of your sweater, add length in the center back with short rows. You can use this technique with any pattern. The goal is to add length without changing the length of the side seams.
Here are 2 methods you can use

title: DAK Opening Stitch Pattern Files
description: A basic review of how to use DAK stitch pattern files provided by Knit it Now in patterns and the Stitch Library.

title: Decorative Looped Edge Finish
description: A looped edge adds a soft finish to your knitting.  Quickly add to either cast on or bind off edges. Because the edges are similar, this is a nice finish for scarves and shawls

title: Tool: Magic Formula (Inches)
description:
Easily shape your knitting with the Magic Formula and no math!
Often used to shorten or lengthen sleeves or add waist shaping, this tool is invaluable when you have a schematic that indicates the dimensions of the piece you want to alter.

title: Tool: Magic Formula (stitches)
description:
Easily shape your knitting with the Magic Formula and no math!
Often used to shorten or lengthen sleeves or add waist shaping, this tool is invaluable and easy to use. Enter in the stitch and row values from your pattern and adjust as needed. The tool will generate custom shaping instructions for you.

title: Band Perfection
description: When creating bands on the machine, which comes first the band or the garment edge?  Watch as we experiment with 2 methods of joining ribbed bands to a garment edge. You may be surprised at the results.

title: Add a Hood to Any Sweater
description:
Adding a hood to any sweater pattern can be easy. There are a few things to consider when designing a hood ... especially for machine knitters. This overview will give you confidence to create your own custom hoodie sweater!
Look for the complete workbook "Add a Hood to ANY Knitting Pattern". 8 hood styles and all the math ... ready for immediate download.

title: Marker Rows
description:
There are times when you will be picking up stitches in the knitting below the current row.  It's helpful to create a marking row for accuracy.

You'd use a marking row when forming a pintuck, creating a hem or picking up stitches. 

Here are 3 methods for creating marker rows.

title: End Needle Selection on Brother Machines
description: When knitting in Fairisle, have you ever found long floats across the work from edge to edge? The culprit is the end needle selection. Learn what this is and what you can do to prevent the floats

title: Outside the Box Practice Vest
description:
Who needs a pattern? For a quick practice project, combine a little imagination with a mishmash of techniques. A small time investment goes a long way toward building your knitting confidence.
  • Cut 'n sew
  • Unusual armhole and neckline binding
  • Crochet Trim
Not just for dolls ... stretch your skills and get creative in your knitting.

title: Neck Band Tool and Tips
description: Shaping and finishing necklines can be one of the more challenging things in machine knitting. Use the Knit it Now Neckline tool to help you create your bands to perfection!

title: Copy a Ready To Wear Sweater
description: Follow along as we examine a ready-to-wear sweater design. Based on 3 criteria, we'll examine the possibility of knitting it on the knitting machine.

title: DesignaKnit Keyboard Shortcuts
description: Want to finish fast using Original Pattern Drafting? Use keyboard shortcuts to make designing easier and faster.

title: DesignaKnit Measuring Tools
description: Tips for using the DAK 8 Measuring tools. Get finished fast with shortcuts. The example measures the front opening and neck edge to calculate the number of stitches to pick up for a cardigan band.

title: DesignaKnit Garment (Japanese) Notation Format
description:
Garment (Japanese) notation knitting instructions can be very easy to follow. Customize the printout of your DesignaKnit knitting instructions so they are visually clear.

Learn to modify the print format of this style of instruction with this tutorial: DesignaKnit | Japanese Notation Formatting

title: DesignaKnit 8/9 Japanese Notation Formatting
description:
Want to customize the printing format of the Garment (Japanese) Notation output? One small change can make the abbreviations easier to follow.

Learn to modify the print format of this style of instruction with this tutorial: DesignaKnit | Japanese Notation Page Format

title: Zig-Zag Lace
description: A graphic eyelet zig zag pattern that can be varied in unlimited ways.  Manually working the transfers isn't too difficult, although your lace carriage would make quick work of this design.

title: Zig-Zag Lace Flags
description:
Based on a simple Zig-Zag Lace stitch pattern, this stitch pattern incorporates multiple stitch transfers. If you are new to lace on the knitting machine, this is a good study in positioning eyelets which are the basis of all lace patterns in knitting.
This pattern is hand manipulated and can be worked on any knitting machine.

title: Decorative Yoke Seam
description: Add some interest when joining seams. Featuring our "waterfall" vest and duster, these techniques can add a designer touch to any seam

title: Machine Knitting Courses
description:
Learn to machine knit the most efficient on-line way possible. Interactive learning courses include videos, practice exercises, question and answer tutorials and more ... watch how easy they are to use.
Try It Yourself - Free Course

title: Blanket Binding
description:
Here's a different method for finishing blanket edges .... Binding!
This is a great alternative to crochet, i-cord and other edge finishing techniques.
It isn't hard and we walk you through 3 methods for applying binding to your blanket.

title: Reversible Band
description: This amazing band encloses the edge of your garment.  Use it for cardigan bands, neckbands or anywhere you want both sides to look beautiful. No ugly bind off edge on the inside.

title: Checkerboard Stitch Pattern
description:
Creating this classic knit and purl checkerboard pattern isn't difficult. Watch as we use the ribber and a little hand manipulation to create it.
This is a truly reversible stitch pattern, perfect for turned back collars, scarves and blankets.
Another method of creating this stitch pattern on a standard gauge machine is to use a transfer carriage. Both Brother and Silver/Singer/Studio offered these accessories and they can save a lot of time. Here's a video

title: Neckline Shaping and the Row Counter
description:
Have you ever been knitting along and realize that the row counter isn't counting? Consider shifting your knitting on the needlebed to prevent headaches.

NOTE: This technique is great if you are hand manipulating or working in plain knitting, but when patterning, you need to maintain the position of the work on the correct needles.

title: E-Wrap Insert
description: Watch as we add a decorative insert between sections with E-wrap.  NOTE: there is no sound on this video

title: DesignaKnit: Neckbands and Collars
description:
DesignaKnit doesn't automatically create PIECES for neckbands and collars. (It does generate knitting instructions)

Learn to create your own neckband and collar PIECES with minimal fuss. Use the power of DAK to manipulate unique collar shapes.

title: Ugly Cast On?
description:
A new knitter wrote that she was doing something wrong when casting on. Turns out that the technique she used was just plain "ugly" for the edge of her project.
Super-Fast Closed Cast on
Beginner Workshop

title: Easy (Lazy) Edge Finish
description: A simple edge finish that is perfect for slits and  neck openings, especially on kids pullovers. A fellow knitter, Jill, asked how to finish the opening on a Baby Pinafore. This technique is fast and looks great!

title: Ravel Cord Tips
description: Cut your ravel cord?  Heaven forbid! Let's talk about alternative ravel cord materials and uses for a machine knitters best friend ... ravel cord.

title: Alter the Color Block Poncho
description:
Ready for a challenge? The Color Block Poncho is easy knitting ... the challenge is in the construction - especially if you want to alter the length or the size.
Watch as we walk through the basic construction and give tips for altering.

title: Color Block Poncho Construction
description: Knit 5 striped pieces, join them as you knit, 2 seams and you'll have this unusual graphic design poncho.

title: DesignaKnit: Manipulate Pieces
description:
Customize pattern pieces in Original Pattern Drafting. Watch as we create a design that will incorporate multiple stitch patterns. Also good for colorblock designs.
Learn to manipulate garment pieces to make it your own!

title: Scrap on Scrap Off
description: Machine knitters often use scrap yarn (waste yarn) to start and end our knitting.  Here are some tips and suggestions for including these techniques in your bag of tricks.

title: Where's my Pattern?
description: Waiting for the delivery of a pattern in your email?  With our Dynamic Patterns, you build a custom pattern based on YOUR gauge. The patterns live in your personal library on the Knit it Now website.

title: Ready, Set, KNIT!
description: We machine knit because we want to get done fast!  With a little preparation, you can finish even faster!  Gather all your tools and supplies BEFORE you get started and eliminate some distraction.

title: Keep on Track when Ripping
description: It's inevitable, making mistakes and ripping. Ever have trouble keeping track of how many rows you knit?  Try this tip.

title: Milk the Cow - Yarn Tension
description: The purpose of the yarn mast is to provide steady, even tension on your working yarn. Sometimes things can go wrong ...

title: Prevent Damage when Partial Knitting
description: Have you ever shaped a neckline and found a row of damaged stitches where you held one side? Prevent damage to your knitting when holding stitches.

title: Need to Tink?
description: Do you need to rip? Frog (rip-it, rip-it, rip-it)? Tink (Knit backwards)? Here's a time-saving tip

title: Fixing Mistakes - Ripping Tips
description: We all make mistakes ... watch as we recover from some recent boo-boos. Includes tips you can use every day

title: Yards per Pound Tool
description:
More and more machine knitters are using hand knitting yarn that is put up in balls, skeins and hanks.
What happens when your favorite is discontinued?

Here are 2 ways to use the yarn information from the ball band to compare yarns and find a replacement.

title: Gauge and Drop
description: Have you ever knit a garment that ended up too long? Do you measure your swatches flat?  Watch as we play with gravity.

title: Double Increases on the Machine
description: 2 methods for adding 2 stitch increases along the edge of your knitting. Our Asymmetric Swirl Shawl uses this technique to create the diagonal design.

title: Asymmetric Swirl Shawlette/Scarf
description: Quick knitting, this adorable Shawlette/Scarf is quick to knit and uses a small amount of yarn. Great gift idea and stash buster, it can be knit on any machine.

title: Wonky Set in Sleeves
description: Why does the sleeve cap have less rows than the armhole opening? Tips for understanding set in sleeve construction.

title: Tuck Basics
description:
Tuck got you stumped? This popular stitch pattern can be worked on any machine.

The secret is UNDERSTANDING what is happening with all the settings on your machine.
No matter what machine you are using, there are 4 Essentials to instructing your machine to knit in tuck.

Follow along as we walk through each step.

title: Setting In Sleeves on the Machine
description:
Setting in set-in sleeves on the knitting machine is a popular way to get sleeves into armholes.

It takes some practice to achieve perfection, but this is a quick way to create a beautiful finish for set in sleeve sweaters.

title: Rip and Rehang
description: Need to rip down a few rows?  Explore 4 tools to help repair a mistake, pick up stitches and save your knitting.

title: Short Row Refresher
description: Short Row Shaping (Partial Knitting) is used in so many ways in machine knitting. If you aren't familiar with this technique, here's a quick refresher.knit-wrap-knit

title: Favorite Bind off
description: An all-time favorite bind off that allows for control over the stretch of the bind off edge. Even if you love the round-the-gatepeg bind off method. You have to try this one!

title: Lifelines: Best Advice EVER!
description:
Prepare for those inevitable mistakes. The best MK advice I've been given.
Learn more about lifelines and fixing mistakes in the Classroom: Fixing Mistakes

title: Shallow Round Neck Shaping
description:
Round Neck shaping with shaped shoulders can be tricky. A shallow round neck (back neckline) is only worked over about 1" of rows, but it's worked in 3 sections. You have to keep your wits about you to get both sides looking great!
This step-by-step video walks through short row shaping the shoulders AND shaping the neckline.

title: DAK: Lace Lessons Learned
description:
****This Video is specific to Brother machines ***** Have you ever received error messages when creating or editing lace stitch Patterns?
"The pattern .... has an invalid sequence of lace symbols at row ().."
or
"The pattern .... has lace transfers on rows () and ()"
Watch as we make DAK happy, eliminate these error messages and create a proper lace pattern.

title: Intro to the DAK Lace Tool
description: Are you new to the Lace Tool?  Here are the basics for getting started

title: Asymmetric V Neck Opening
description: An off-center V neck opening can be a flattering addition to your design. Charting this design can be easy with the Knit it Now Magic Formula Tools ... no math!

title: DAK: Asymmetric V-Neckline
description: Quickly create an off-center v-neck opening using Standard Garment Shaping and Original pattern Drafting. Make a one-of-a-kind design with DAK.

title: Oops - When Bad Things happen to Good Knitters
description:
Even with simple knitting projects like our "Right Angles Blanket", things can go wrong. The secret is to take a deep breath, don't panic and fix it!
Watch as we fix some common issues.

Right Angles Blanket Pattern

DIY Blanket Course

title: LIfelines: Scrap off Method
description:
Scrapping off your work before starting a new section or just to preserve a section of your knitting is worth the extra effort.
If (when) mistakes happen give yourself the gift of being able to rip back to your lifeline and not have to start again.

title: Interrupted Patterning (Part 3)
description: Knitting in stitch pattern with Brother machines, we can knit both sides of a neckline at the same time. Create a neckline outline as you knit to prepare your piece for cut 'n sew. Part 1 Part 2

title: 2x2 Ribbed Lace
description: Take plain 'ol 2x2 ribbing and make it fabulous with a bit of hand manipulation

title: DAK - Add a Waistline
description: Add waist shaping for a dress or sweater and show off your hourglass shape! This is a basic exercise to get practice using the Original Pattern Drafting tools - especially the table feature to accurately position the waist shaping.

title: Figure 8 Bind Off
description:
Here's a loose bind off that can be used anywhere you want an extra stretchy edge.
Consider using this as bind off for ribbing. Simply transfer the ribber needles to the main bed and work the Figure 8 bind off.

title: DAK 8 - Stitch/Row Totals
description: Accurately determine the EXACT size of a piece in DesignaKnit. Position words, motifs or stitch patterns. Know exactly how large to knit a piece for cut 'n sew.

title: Knit it Now Tools
description:
You may not want to draft your own knitting patterns, but sometimes you need to modify a pattern for fit.
Knit it Now tools takes the tedious math out of making changes to your patterns.

title: Use HK Patterns for MKing
description: Explore our Course: Using Hand Knitting Patterns for Machine Knitting.

title: Accurate Gauge Measurement
description:
Measuring your swatch to find the correct gauge is the most important step in making sure your garment will fit.

This tutorial covers 2 different methods of measuring gauge: working with gauge rulers and using a standard ruler. Includes a discussion about the green ruler, yellow ruler and blue rulers

title: Replay: Knitting Disasters - Prevent and Cure
description:
It's happened to us all ... the work drops off the machine (always at the worst moment). We drop stitches or knit in a knot.

Don't feel alone! Take a deep breath, take a walk and come back to the machine with fresh eyes and "just do it" to get back on track.

  • Tips for preventing problems
  • Techniques for fixing boo-boos
  • When to start over

title: Take off Live Stitches
description:
Use a hand knitting needle to remove all (or some) needles from the needlebed. Temporarily hold stitches:
  • To reverse knitting (create purl bumps)
  • Re-position the knitting on the needlebed
  • Hold the stitches to join later

title: DAK 8 - Duplicate a Sweater
description: One powerful trick to use DesignaKnit to duplicate a sweater you love (or a hand knitting pattern). If you know the measurements, enter them in DAK and use the pattern again and again at any gauge.

title: Curved Hems - The NO MATH Way
description:
Curved hems, deep and shallow are always popular. Shirt Tail hems at the side seams of sweaters, or curved hems at the front edge of cardigans can be added to any knitting pattern.
Here's a no-math method to create your own designer curved hems.
NOTE: [01:57] When you examine the placement of the shaping, consider the method of knitting. To shape with short rows, the increases need to be worked EVERY-OTHER-ROW. Draw your line accordingly.

title: What's a Charting Device?
description:
These handy knitting machine accessories have been called a number of names and come in different forms. Knit Leader, Knit radar ... the concept is the same.
Instead of using someone else's pattern, gauge and size differences, draw what you want to knit based on your measurements.
If you've never used or seen a charting device, here are the basics to get you started.

title: DesignaKnit - Lengthen Sleeves
description: 3 ways to adjust sleeve length in DesignaKnit.  Use either Original Pattern Drafting or Standard Garment Shaping.  There is no excuse for sleeves that are the wrong length!

title: DesignaKnit - Place Markers
description: Placing markers in DAK can be helpful in placing motifs, indicating row repeats or positioning darts. Often overlooked this handy tool can be very useful.

title: Bust Darts with DesignaKnit
description: Modify a sweater in Original Pattern Drafting to add bust darts.  Let DAK do the math for you!

title: Manual Wrap for Short Row Shaping
description: Manual Wrap for Short Row Shaping (no sound)

title: Hung Hem with Cast on Comb
description: Try this!  Here's a quick way to hang a hem without re-hanging each stitch from waste yarn.

title: Dak 8 - Upper Arm Adjustment
description: Adjust the upper arm dimension in DesignaKnit Standard Garment Styling BEFORE using Original Pattern Drafting.

title: Dak 8&9 - Shoulder Slope
description: For best results, create shoulder shaping in Standard Garment Styling, not Original Pattern Drafting.

title: Fit: Wrinkles at the Armhole
description:
Adding shaped shoulders to any knitting pattern will really improve the fit. Explore the reasons why.
This video is part of the Course: Yes! Knits that Fit which explains in more detail how to add shoulder shaping to existing patterns

title: Best Machine Knitting Advice
description: 2 "rules" for successful machine knitting.  Want garments that fit?  Don't ignore this crucial advice

title: For Success: Plan Ahead
description: One thing that will guarantee success with your knitting. READ!

title: The Secret to Getting Good Fit
description:
Don't EXPECT any knitting pattern to fit you without alterations. Learn to make changes to customize patterns for your success.
The video refers to our course "Yes! Knits that Fit"

title: Dak 8 - Curved hemline
description: Create curved hem corners at the side seams of a sweater.  Use Original Pattern drafting to create the curves.

title: Alter a Sweater Front for Baby Bump or Front Porch
description:
You can alter the front of a sweater to cover a large tummy. The front and back don't have to match.
Here are 2 ways to add both length and width to sweater fronts.

title: DAK - Alter Patterns - Sweater Front
description: If you need more tummy room in your sweaters, use DAK to lengthen and widen the front of your sweater. Use Original Pattern Drafting to easily make the pattern alterations needed and generate a custom knitting pattern.

title: Dak 8 - Armhole Alterations
description: DAK offers 2 options for measuring the depth of armholes.  Explore both methods and examine when to best use each.

title: Brother Single Bed Color Changer
Radiant Eyelet Lace
description:
Beautiful hand manipulated lace - 12 row repeat with only 2 manual stitch transfer rows per repeat.
Easy to memorize and "read" the pattern.

title: Calculating Armhole Bands
description:
Calculating armhole bands for vests and sleeveless sweaters is a bit different than calculating for a straight edge.

There are 2 considerations:
  • The shape of the armhole
  • Picking up stitches to rows
This tutorial provides in-depth instruction and examination of the steps for creating perfect armhole bands.

title: Stabilizer for Cut 'n Sew Excellence
description:
Here's a product that will improve your cut 'n sew technique. Gain sewing control, improve the look of your edges and speed up the process.
Old dogs CAN learn new tricks! Try this yourself!

UPDATE: Fellow knitter, Carin shared that there is a clear wash-away stabilizer that is used for embroidery machines that would allow us to put it on top of the knitting. Here's one I found on Amazon
Thanks Carin!

Suggested: Knit it Now Neckline Template
Multiple sizes for round neck perfection.

title: Scrap Off
description: Safely remove your knitting from the machine without dropping stitches or binding off. Scrapping off is used whenever you want to leave live, open stitches to pick up later. Think of this as a FAST bind off with options.

title: Sock Toe Shaping - Improved
description:
Compare sock toe shaping techniques on a flat bed machine. Traditional Short Row shaping vs hand knit decrease method.
Which do you prefer?

title: Partial Bind Off
description:
Many times we are instructed to bind off a few stitches at the beginning of a row. For example, when shaping an armhole.

What do you do with the last loop of the bind off? More importantly, how can we improve the look of the edge where the partial bind off ends?

title: Design your own stitch patterns
description:
When creating your own stitch patterns, it is critical to keep your gauge in mind.
No matter what method you use, DAK, Pencil and Paper, Punchcards, your success depends on understanding the ratio of stitches to rows.
Take a look at some before and after designs as they relate to the final knitting gauge.

title: Toes and Heels - Automatic Wrap
description: Learn to use short row shaping with AUTOMATIC wrapping to shape toes and heels of socks.

title: Seaming Mock Ribbing
description:
Mock ribbing is a great alternative for machine knitters to use instead of hand manipulating knit and purl stitches, using a ribber or hand knitting ribbing.
Here are some tricks for beautiful seams when working mock ribbing.
Extra Seaming tip:
  • Start seaming on the public side of the hat at the join point
  • 1. Leave a tail and stitch from the join point to the fold
  • 2. turn the knitting and stitch the "inside" of the fold
  • Take the yarn out of your darning needle
  • 3. turn the knitting to continue seaming
  • Re-thread the darning needle with the other end of the seaming strand
  • Seam from the join point to the top of the hat.
  • Secure both ends

title: Create and Position a Single Motif In DAK
description:
Create and position a single motif in DAK. Create a Welcome Banner with a single letter on each triangle.

The techniques used will show you how to put any single motif on a sweater, cuff, collar or anywhere!

Use these ideas to create and precisely place Christmas motifs on stockings and accessories.

These are not beginner techniques. You will be using multiple tools in both Original Pattern Shaping and Stitch Designer.

title: Hold That Needle! Understanding the ‘Hold Position’ on Any Machine
description: "Place Needles in hold" Huhh??? For new knitters, especially hand knitters, this concept may be foreign.  Let's explore the hold position and it's uses.  We'll talk about the similarities and differences between different machine brands

title: Fancy Sock Start-to-Finish
description:
Get creative!
This style of sock allows for different stitch patterns on sole and heel by knitting them separately.

title: Dak 8 Copy Curved Hem Shaping
description: Here are 4 methods of replicating shaping changes from one piece to another. Our example uses curved hems. Create curves on the front, then use one of the methods presented to copy the curve to the back. Use Original Pattern Drafting to create any shape you want.

title: Add Fringe to your Knitting
description:
Fringe can add the perfect touch to your knitting.

Learn to add fringe on the knitting machine

title: Tuck Lace on a Manual Machine
description: Tuck with needles out of work (tuck lace) is a beautiful technique that can be worked on any knitting machine.  Keeping needles out of work combined with tuck stitch creates lighter weight fabric for a variety of uses.

title: Cheat Sheets for Hand Manipulation
description:
With non-patterning machines and any time you want to work a hand manipulated stitch pattern, there's usually a lot of counting of needles involved. Here are cheat sheets to help hand selecting needles a snap!

Use with 3.6mm, 4.5mm, 6mm, 6.5mm, 7mm, 8mm, 9mm knitting machines.

Don't know the pitch of your machine? The instructions help you select your cheat sheet as well as suggestions for using them.

Download these helpful tools and you'll be knitting cables, lace, and other stitch patterns quickly and accurately ... without having to repeatedly count needles!

Download the sheets

title: Single Row Stripes with Free Pass
description:
For an interesting play on color, try one-row stripes! Use as an all-over pattern, or intersperse single rows of color here and there. This could also be used to break up color pooling with variegated yarns.
Note:
Keep your row count in mind when using this technique. When you free pass, the row counter advances, but you haven't knit a row. You need to manually adjust the row counter each time. (If the row count is even, the carriage should be on the right.)

title: Slip Cast on - Extra FAST!
description: Use the slip setting on your machine for an extra fast closed cast on. PLUS use the cast on strand to quickly gather the edge ... great for knitting hats from the top down.

title: Plaiting Feeder on the LK-150
description:
The plating feeder controls 2 working strands of yarn and positions them so one strand lays on the purl side of the knitting and the other strand lays on the knit side of the work.

This video explores threading the feeder and "which side is which?"

title: Fairisle on the LK-150
description: Even though the LK-150 is a manual machine, you can still create fairisle (stranded) knitting. Watch as we break down the steps to further your understanding of your machine.

title: Yarn Bobbins for Intarsia
description: Control those strands when knitting in intarsia. 2 quick (and inexpensive) ways to make your own yarn bobbins.

title: Intarsia with a Manual Machine
description: Knitting intarsia on a manual machine is completely do-able! You don't need an intarsia carriage. It's a matter of  taking charge of your carriage and needle positions to knit ONLY the blocks of stitches you want to knit.

title: Short Row in Pattern
description: Working short rows while knitting in pattern shouldn't be intimidating.  Watch as we short row increase and decrease while knitting in tuck

title: Christmas Elf Hat
description: Create a pattern for an Elf Hat - make it any length you want. Let us do the math and you be the designer!

title: Short  Rows in Knitweave
description: Here's the one secret to successfully doing short row shaping while working in Knit Weave.  Prevent holes AND secure the weaving yarn for a beautiful finish when shaping.

title: Using the McMorran Yarn Balance
description:
Using a McMorran Yarn Balance (or scale) allows you to identify the yards per pound (ypp) when it is unknown.

This tool is available from many sources specializing in weaving yarn . They are invaluable if you regularly use yarns of different weights or you are trying to find out the ypp of a skeined yarn. They are available for weighing yarn in both metric and imperial units.

Included are the steps for using this tool.

title: Beautiful Knit Weave Edges
description: One little tip makes all the difference when working Knitweave. Learn how to create beautiful edges and a seaming stitch for finishing perfection.

title: DAK- Raglan Sleeves
description: Modify the size of the upper arm and the neckline changes .. what??? When designing your own raglan sweaters in Standard Garment Styling, it's important to understand the relationship between the pieces so you end up with a raglan design that works for you.

title: Slipped Chain Edge  Finish
description: Slip the edge stitches as if to knit - this instruction is a basic edge finish for hand knitters.  Machine knitters can easily duplicate this look. Watch how you can add beautiful edges to your knitting.

title: Shaped Crown Hat on the Machine
description:
Ready for a challenge? Knitting a shaped crown requires you transfer a lot of stitches. But you only do the transfers for 2” and a garter bar makes the process go quickly. This technique can be used for a beanie style hat or a slouchy beret.

Check the Quick Win for the patterns (adult and kids) and everything you need to knit your own beanie.

title: No Ribber? Ribbing Cast On Options
description: 4 cast on choices for hand manipulated ribbing. From fast 'n easy to a gorgeous tubular cast on, you have options for getting your ribbing started

title: Ribber E-Wrap Cast On
description:
For a quick, stretch cast on, try e-wrap on both beds. This one is a little tricky, but many knitters love it.
This technique offers an alternate wrapping method for the cast on.
Compare the method Ribber e-Wrap Cast on 2

title: Waffle Stitch (Ribber)
description: A beautiful variation of 1x1 ribbing that's easy to knit with no automatic patterning or hand manipulation.

title: Open Cast on vs. Closed Cast On
description: There are many ways to get your knitting started.  Compare open cast on and closed cast on methods.

title: Double E-wrap 3 techniques
description:
The basic e wrap is one of the first cast on methods that most machine knitters learn. It is similar to the thumb cast on that is a hand knitting beginners technique.

Many patterns call for a double e-wrap. Like so many things in knitting, this term can mean many things.

We will explore 3 variations, compare the differences and explore uses other than for beginning a knitted piece.

title: Sleeves in the Round
description:
With a ribber you can quickly knit tubes of fabric. Increases and decreases for shaping can also be worked while knitting in the round.
Watch as we explore this concept for knitting sleeves with no seams.

title: Adjusting a Ribber
description: Here are tips for troubleshooting problems with your ribber

title: Lacy Ribber Hem
description: 8 rows - easy main bed transfers and Voila!  A beautiful, feminine hem

title: Loopy Ribber Hem
description: Simple 2 row trim, transferring stitches from the main bed to the ribber to create a delicate, lacy (loopy) edge.

title: Racking with Flat Rib
description: Examine the basics of racking with a simple pattern worked in flat rib.  Learn the settings for your machine.  This will start you on a journey of discovery into the huge world of racking.

title: Diagonal Shaping
description:
Easy knitting versus accuracy. When knitting diagonals, we use the magic formula (Diophantine Calculation) to determine the shaping instructions. For example. Decrease 1 stitch every 3 rows, 1 stitch every 2 rows.
Variations on these instructions can make a big difference in the shape of your diagonal shaping.

title: DAK Diagonal Shaping
description:
Explore Diagonal Shaping choices in Original Pattern Drafting.
Learn more about shaping methods Diagonal Shaping

title: Shaping in 1x1 Ribbing
description: Shaping in 1x1 ribbing shouldn't be intimidating. Take time to practice these simple techniques and you'll soon be an expert!

title: Rescue Ribbing Oops
description: Oops! You've dropped a few ribber stitches or dropped the work from the machine.  All may not be lost.  Watch for tips for rehanging ribbing after a disaster.

title: Change your Email and Password
description:
You can change your own Knit it Now Password:
Click "Account"
Click "Modify Profile"
NOTE: We do not store credit card or payment information.

title: Scrap and Ravel
description: Commonly used, cast on method for closed or open cast on

title: Short Row Increasing in 1x1 ribbing
description: Get familiar with short rows while working on the double bed.  1x1 shaping is a great place to start.  Learn the technique and examine the wraps for perfection

title: Short Rows in Full Needle Rib
description: Work short row shaping (partial knitting) while knitting full needle rib.  Even though all the needles on both beds are in work, don't be intimidated by this.

title: Swatching is NOT Optional
description: If you don't knit, dress and measure your swatches correctly, YOU WON'T HAVE SUCCESS with your knitting. PERIOD.

title: DAK: Curve Tool
description:
In Original Pattern Drafting, the Curve Tool is a powerful addition to your designing. It has quite a few options and can be a bit confusing. Get some experience with this tool by exploring some of the options while creating a round neckline.

DAK 9 Update: DAK 9 now offers Bezier Curves for even more curve design possibilities. Check out the LearnDesignaKnit.com course "DesignaKnit9: What's New" to learn more.

title: Slip Stitch on Brother Machines
description:
Slip stitch is one of the basic techniques that can be worked on any machine. Hand manipulated or worked with automatic patterning, there are many, many uses for this technique.
From Free Pass to complicated, highly textured stitch patterns, understanding slip is essential for all machine knitters.

Have a Studio/Singer/Silver machine? Here's your video

NOTE: If you have a Toyota machine, substitute the "Empty" setting for the "Part" setting.

title: Slip Stitch on Silver/Singer/Studio Machines
description:
Slip stitch is one of the basic techniques that can be worked on any machine. Hand manipulated or worked with automatic patterning, there are many, many uses for this technique.
From Free Pass to complicated, highly textured stitch patterns, understanding slip is essential for all machine knitters.

Have a Brother Machine? Here's your tutorial

title: DAK: Design with Stitches and Rows
description:
When copying knitting patterns in DAK (or creating from scratch) there's one tool that can be extra helpful. Switching between inches/cm and stitches/rows gives you the precision to copy from an existing pattern.
Once you have the design copied, you can then easily change gauge and be confident that the dimensions are the same as the original

title: Right Angles Blanket - Start to Finish
description:
Fun, easy knitting with a graphic appeal. Great beginner blanket with unusual construction that isn't hard. The finished blanket is square. Want a rectangle? Knit two.
Watch as we knit ours.
The yarn and the angles make this design special.

title: Garter Eyelets
description: Decorative eyelet and garter ridge insert. Alternate with multiple color stripes for fun, happy sweater.

title: Replay: Garter Stitch on the Machine
description:
One of the first surprises for most new machine knitters is the fact that the humble garter stitch is problematic on the knitting machine.
Because our needles face in one direction and they form uniform stitches in one direction, we can easily produce stockinette stitch (translated knit 1 row, purl 1 row) but to knit every row?
Let's talk about the many ways that we can add garter stitch to our machine knits.

title: Slip Stitch on Non-Patterning Machines
description:
Add beautiful texture to your knitting with pattern stitches created by skipping (or slipping) over pattern needles.

Punchcard and electronic machines make knitting slip stitches easy, but this technique can also be created on non-patterning machines with a bit of hand manipulation.

title: LK-150 and DAK
description:
Do you have DesignaKnit (or considering it)? You CAN put it to use with your LK-150 machine (or Brother KX350 or any non-patterning/non-electronic machine).

You can find the cable HERE

Here are the features of DesignaKnit you can use with your machine.

title: Tuck Lessons Learned
description: Measuring and calculating accurate gauge when knitting in tuck can be problematic. Here are 8 tips learned the hard way

title: Brother 970 Row Counter
description:
If you don't have a mechanical row counter for your Brother 970, you can use the CB-1 box as your row counter, even if you aren't doing any patterning work.
Using this feature can be a bit obscure. This tutorial walks you through all the steps.

title: Crochet Button Loops
description: Use crochet to crate button loops.  As you work crochet along the edge, work chain loops at the same time

title: Knitting Words with DAK
description: Adding text to your knitting is a snap with DesignaKnit. Explore the power of the text tool by adding a name to the top of a Christmas Stocking.  This feature can be used with both electronic machines and punchcard machines (with stitch limitations)

title: Punchcard Basics
description:
Automatic patterning with punchcards can seem almost magical. Let's dispel some of the mystery, learn the basics and take steps to punchcard machine mastery.
Identify Punchcards

title: Identify Punchcards
description: "I have a stack of cards and don't know what they are for".  Learn how punchcards create stitch patterns and identify different cards and their uses

title: Kitchener Join (Grafting)
description:
Neatly join 2 pieces of knitting, stitches to stitches by grafting. More information about this technique can be found in the "Seaming Perfection" Classroom
** no sound **

title: Punchcard: Where to Start?
description: Position a punchcard in the punchcard mechanism, so the patterning starts at Row 1

title: Stitch Pattern with Every-Other-Needle
description:
Modify a stitch pattern to be used when knitting over every-other-needle. Create the punchcard to mimic the original design, but only pattern over the needles in work.

Remember: to choose which needles to put in out of work position, the stitch pattern is CENTERED on the machine.

title: Unbox an LK-150
description: Whoo Hoo!  You have a new-to-you LK-150 knitting machine!  This popular machine offers so  many possibilities for both new and experienced machine knitters.  Watch as we un-box our machine an get you started on the right foot

title: Milk the Cow: Lk150
description: A small adjustment to prevent big problems

title: Plaiting on the machine
description:
Knit 2 strands of yarn together and let the machine position them so you view one color on one side of the knitting and the 2nd color on the other side of the knitting.
This technique can be used on both the single and double bed. It's a great way to bulk up finer yarns and play with color and texture.
Click here for an LK-150 plaiting specific tutorial

title: Toes and Heels - Manual Wrap
description: Learn to use short row shaping with MANUAL WRAPPING to shape toes and heels of socks.

title: Open Cast On with Scrap and Ravel
description: An open cast on secures the first row of knitting, so the stitches can be picked up by hand or re-hung on the machine. Using scrap yarn and ravel cord is the fastest and easiest way to create an open cast on.

title: Chain Cast On with Scrap and Ravel
description: This closed cast on creates a firm, decorative edge.  Using scrap and ravel makes the knitting easier.

title: e-Wrap Cast On with Scrap and Ravel
description: This closed cast on creates a stretchy, all-purpose edge.  Using scrap and ravel makes the knitting easier.

title: Favorite Bind Off
description: Stitch thru stitch bind off that is worked so YOU control the size of the bind off stitches and the tension of the bind off edge.  Make it as firm or loose as you like. No guesswork

title: Kangaroo Pocket
description:
A kangaroo pocket adds a fun, casual, and practical touch to sweaters.

Here's a technique for adding the pocket with very little hand finishing. Joining the top and bottom edges as you knit the sweater front creates a seamless, professional touch.

Check out the Kangaroo Pocket Pattern

title: DAK: Kangaroo Pocket
description:
Create a kangaroo pocket piece to your dimensions with DesignaKnit. With just a few steps, you'll be ready to knit either a curved or straight pocket to add to your hoodie.
Create your pocket with DAK or Use the Knit it Now Kangaroo Pocket Pattern

title: DAK: EZ Cut 'N Sew Neckline Template
description: Use DAK to create templates for Cut 'n Sew. Use a little-known feature of DAK to make quick work of creating a personalized neckline template you can use again and again.

title: Cut N Sew - Beaded Band
description:
After working a basic Cut ‘n Sew band, add a row of beads to decorate the neckband.

There are as many possibilities for this technique as there are bead styles!

title: Cut N Sew - Chained Edge Band
description:
Using the chain cast on technique on both edges of the band adds a decorative finishing touch. This style of band is perfect for cut and sew shaping.
But it can be used on any knitted edge. It creates a very neat band on both sides of the garment.
NOTE: This finish is not as elastic as many of the other options. Be sure to use this finish on an neck opening that is large enough to go over the head.

title: Cut n Sew - Bands in Pattern
description: Consider using fairisle, tuck, slip, or reverse stockinette for bands with texture and contrast.

title: Cut N Sew - Rolled Edge Band
description:
This is an easy to knit band that is neat and “formal” on both sides or the garment, encasing the neck edge, but the roll adds a casual look to a garment
This style of band is perfect for cut and sew shaping.  But it can be used on any knitted edge. It creates a very neat band on both sides of the garment.

title: 2 Piece Industrial Band
description: Beautiful on both sides, this 2 piece band can be used on any edge.  Perfect for enclosing cut'n sew edges, it can also be used for button bands.  Lots of finishing options make it a go-to for all machine knitters

title: Band Pickup Tool
description: Calculating how many stitches to pick up for a cardigan band can be a challenge. Use the Knit it Now Band Pickup Tool for beautiful bands.

title: Buttonhole Placement Tool (horizontal)
description: Precisely position your buttonholes with no math!

title: Gauge Calculator Tool
description:
The Gauge Calculator helps you determine the stitch and row gauge of your knitted swatch.

Try the calculator

title: Slope Tool
description:
Use to calculate shoulder shaping.
Enter your gauge, width and depth (height) and Knit In Now will produce your line by line instructions for your slopes.

title: Reform a column of Purl Stitches
description: Use the latch tool to reform a column of stitches to purl stitches. This is the basic technique for creating ribbing on a flatbed knitting machine

title: Using Gauge Rulers
description:
Gauge Rulers (scales) are NOT machine specific! They are stitch and row gauge specific. Let's explore using gauge rulers with some mystery swatches and get comfortable with the logic behind these useful tools.
Do you have a white or purple gauge ruler? Determine what scale it is so you can put it to use.

title: DesignaKnit: Yarn Calculator
description: Let DesignaKnit calculate how much yarn you need for your project.  Weigh and measure your swatch and DAK will use the stitch count of your pattern to calculate.  The bonus is an estimate of colors if designing with more than one color

title: 1234 Edge Finish
description: Crochet look edge that is easy to knit and can be used on long sections. 2 Variations are included for you to try. This is a firm, hand-manipulated, never-ending trim that can be used on necklines, hems, blankets.. you name it!

title: DAK to Brother 970 Download
description:
Creating your own stitch patterns (or modifying stitch patterns) is not difficult when using the Brother 970 and DAK.
Perhaps you see a stitch pattern in a magazine, you can enter the pattern directly to the 970 CB-1 computer, but the screen is quite small. It is much easier to create the stitch pattern in DAK, use a connecting cable and download it to the CB-1 box.
This tutorial will walk you through the basic steps. Included are common error messages.

title: Brother 970 Create a Stitch Pattern
description:
You can create your own stitch patterns directly in the 970 CB-1 Box. Be sure to review the introductory tutorial for the basic concepts.

This tutorial covers creating a simple stitch pattern. Think of it as punching holes in a punchcard ... only much easier!

title: Brother 970 Position a Stitch Pattern - Part 1
description:
This tutorial is the next in a series covering using the CB-1 box on your electronic 970 knitting machine.

Once you have a design in memory of the 970 (using the built in stitches, your own designs, or downloads from another source) you need to position the pattern and prepare to knit.

This is part 1 of 2 tutorials on this subject. It walks you through the steps and includes many helpful tips.

Part 2

title: Brother 970 Position a Stitch Pattern - Part 2
description:
This tutorial is the next in a series covering using the CB-1 box on your electronic 970 knitting machine.

The CB-1 box allows you to combine stitch patterns to make your knitting unique!

This is part 2 of 2 tutorials on this subject. It walks you through the steps and includes many helpful tips.

Part 1

title: Brother 970 Stitch Pattern Variations
description:
The electronics of the CB-1 box allow you to easily modify stitch patterns and make them unique! With a few steps you can reverse or elongate a design plus much more! The possibilities are almost endless!

This tutorial assumes you are familiar with programming stitch patterns on this machine. It covers the variations available on the CB-1 box.

Don't have a 970? Many of these options are available on other machines. These examples may spark your creativity on your machine!

title: Simple Eyelet Transfers - Silver/Singer/Studio
description:
Use your Silver/Singer/Studio Lace carriage to make quick work of simple eyelet transfers.
Practice using your lace carriage and including more complicated designs in your knitting will be a breeze!

Do you have a Brother Lace Carriage? Check out this tutorial

title: Cast on for Points
description: When instructed to cast on 2-4 stitches, using a cast on rag really comes in handy. Discover this trick for an easier cast on over a few needles.

title: Provisional Knitting
description: When knitting socks and mittens in the round, you may want to add and "afterthought" heel or a thumb opening. Using provisional stitches lets you safely leave holes.

title: Slotted Thumbs for Mittens
description: Another thumb style for mittens that works well in pattern. Watch as we knit a slotted thumb, with tips for success

title: Sleeve Shaping: No Joggies
description: When shaping the cap of a set in sleeve, this one trick will create a smoother shape, making it easier to set in the sleeve to the armhole

title: Brother Lace Carriage
description:
Brother Standard Gauge machines offered a separate lace carriage to automatically transfer stitches to create eyelets and lace patterns.

Combined with the punchcard or electronics, a lace carriage can make fast work of this technique. This video is a quick overview of how they work

title: Backward E-Wrap
description: There are times when you need to e-wrap cast on from right to left. (or the opposite direction that feels natural to you). This is one skill that you need for your bag of tricks It's used when knitting our Upside Down Raglan Sweater

title: Lace: Multiple Stitch Transfers
description:
k2tog (knit 2 together) is commonly used to create sections of lace. Explore transferring multiple stitches in different directions to create k2tog. Both manual machines and automatic patterning machines are included.
Look at now only the "how" but learn to read punchcards, electronics. Learn to translate HK patterns for lace carriages.

Here's Part 2

title: Lace: Multiple Stitch Transfers Part 2
description:
A beautiful lace technique is to transfer stitches so the transfers are worked a few stitches away from the eyelet they create. This technique combined with more simple eyelets is the basis for many beautiful lace patterns.
Learn to work (and understand) this type of lace transfers on both manual and automatic patterning machines. Translate hand knit stitch pattern diagrams to machine knitting punchcards and electronics.

Here's Part 1

title: DAK - Sideways Cardigan
description: Create a sideways knit cardigan with set-in sleeves that fits you!

title: Fisherman Rib on a Manual Machine
description:
Hand manipulated knit and purl stitches PLUS tuck EQUALS Fisherman rib. This classic stitch pattern is thick, warm, textured, reversible and stretchy. It's perfect for scarves, earwarmers, hats, fingerless mitts ... whatever you can imagine.
With this technique you can work this on any manual machine, including the LK-150 and Brother KX350.

Although demonstrated on an LK150 - this technique can be worked on ANY machine without a ribber

title: Sideways Sweater Waist Shaping
description: Sideways knit sweaters can be boxy looking.  Adding waist shaping can show off your curves.

title: Twisted Ear Warmer
description: A rectangle, a little twist, an invisible seam and Voila!  A fast 'n easy, fun, Twisted Ear Warmer for winter wear.

title: Interactive Patterns
description: Follow your pattern on your tablet for easier knitting.

title: Collars for Machine Knitters
description: Adding a collar to your sweater design isn't hard.  You can be the designer with a little planning and an understanding of collar construction.

title: Wire Weight Hanger (7 Hanger)
description: Wire weight hangers AKA 7 weight hangers are invaluable for adding additional weight to the edges when knitting with the ribber.

title: Replace a Needle LK-150
description:
Remove and replace needles on the LK150. Tips for correct insertion, easily done

Purchase replacement needles from Knit it Now

title: Spikey Scarf from Knit-1
description:
Here's a fun, textured scarf that is sure to impress! Watch as we detail the partial knitting (short rows) that form the pyramids.

Not only is this a fun knitting project, it's a great exercise in working short row shaping (a machine knitters's must-have skill).
If working short rows is a mystery to you, check out the classroom All About Short Rows
Here's the FREE pattern

title: Using the Pattern | Susanna's Blanket
description:
Walk through with us as we prepare to knit Susanna's blanket. Estimate yarn and use the interactive knitting pattern format.
Susanna's Blanket Pattern

title: SSK | YO | k2tog | PSSO
description:
k2tog, ssk, psso, yo. How do these hand knitting terms translate to machine knitting?
Whether you are hand manipulating lace on your machine or you are creating your own stitch patterns, (either punchcard or electronics), it's important you understand how lace is formed on the machine.

title: 5 Reasons for Poorly Fitting Sweaters
description:
Have you ever knit a sweater that didn't fit? It's happened to all of us.
Here are 5 Reasons for poorly fitting sweaters
Your preferences, your choice of pattern and your knitting techniques all contribute to having success in machine knitting sweaters.

title: What MK patterns do you use?
description:
What machine knitting patterns do you use? Even though we don't have many publications dedicated to machine knitting these days, we do have options.
Hand knitting patterns, vintage patterns, Knit it Now patterns ... which type is best for you?

Explore 6 machine knitting pattern methods and discover your favorite.

title: Using Skinny yarn on any machine
description:
Expand your horizons by using skinny yarn on any machine. Although demonstrated on an LK-150, the ideas in this experiment apply to all machines.
The video refers to "get-acquainted" swatches. Watch the video here

title: Get-Acquainted Swatch
description:
You have a new to you yarn that you'd like to knit with and where do you start? Now the ball band may gave you some information about the suggested needles to use for hand knitting and what stitches you might get, but as machine knitters, this doesn't tell us anything. This doesn't tell us what tension to turn on the tension dial of your machine.

Let's spend some time today playing with a get-acquainted swatch.

title: Prickly Pear Overview
description:
The Prickly Pear Pullover is a basic, no-fuss, easy-to-knit sweater. Featuring rolled hems and top down sleeves, there is minimal finishing.
You can knit this quickly. Add stitch patterns, hand manipulation, hems or ribbing and use this as a blank canvas for your creativity. Quickly knit 5 pieces and you're done!

title: What is Knit it Now?
description:
What is Knit It Now? It’s so much more than patterns or tutorials—it’s a complete resource for machine knitters! In this video, I’ll walk you through everything we offer, from dynamic, customizable patterns to our extensive learning tools, weekly tips, and a supportive worldwide community.

Whether you're just getting started or looking to expand your skills, Knit It Now is here to help you succeed and feel confident with your machine.

title: PSSO Decorative Center Double Decrease
description:
Borrowed from the hand knitting world, this textured, columnar stitch pattern with or without eyelets magically forms a scalloped edge.
Use it in a single column for an accent or use this technique for an impressive all-over design.
Hand knitting instructions may read PSSO or k3tog. Learn to "translate" this to the machine

title: Shoulder Opening for Kids Pullovers
description: For Kids pullovers, it's a good idea to leave one shoulder open to allow the sweater to go over the head. Use this technique with any knitting pattern

title: Knit it Now Learning Library
description: Explore the Knit it Now Learning Library. Navigate the over 500 tutorials and find what you need when you need it.

title: Hip/Tummy Shaping
description: If you need extra room in the hip/tummy area, you can shape the side seams of your sweater.  When you work this shaping, to prevent the front and back from riding up, add some length to the center front and back with short rows.

title: Double Decreases
description: Explore how to work left and right leaning double decreases on the machine.

title: "Knit" at Knit it Now
description: The heart and soul of the website is the "KNIT" section. It not only contains all of our Dynamic patterns, it holds a wealth of resources for your knitting.

title: Upside Down Stitches
description: Something odd happens when you pick up stitches from a cast on edge ... a stitch gets "lost". Explore the reason and solutions

title: End Stitch Presser Plate
description:
When knitting with the ribber, sometimes the end stitches can be problematic. Some machines also have End stitch presser plates to help the end stitches knit cleanly.
Shown are the presser plates for a Brother KR-850 standard gauge machine. Your machine may not have this accessory or it may look differently.

title: Lifelines: Ravel Cord Method
description:
If disaster strikes, it's good to have a lifeline - a row where you've secured your stitches. You can rip back to this row, easily pick up the stitches and start knitting again without starting from the beginning of your piece.
A little time to insert a lifeline, prevents tears!

title: DesignaKnit: Join Pieces
description: Create a kids cardigan without side seams using the DAK "join" feature. Eliminate the seams and make have perfectly aligned motifs in the body of the sweater. The join feature is very useful and a tool that every DAK user should know.

title: 2 Step Buttonholes
description: Neatly add buttonholes to bands. This 2 step process takes a bit of time ... but it's sooo worth the effort!

title: Ear Flaps with Short Rows
description: Quickly knit doubled Flaps for Ear Flap hats. These are an option in our Dynamic, Perfect FitEar Flap Hat Collection pattern

title: DesignaKnit-Position Buttonholes
description: Let DAK quickly position your buttonholes. With just a few steps accurately place either vertical or horizonal buttonholes

title: DAK: Triangles
description: Create a triangle shawl to your desired size. Take your needlebed limitations into consideration and let DAK estimate the yarn needed.

title: DAK: Markers
description: Inserting markers as we knit, helps with seaming and joining. Use the DesignaKnit Markers feature and add markers to be used with the Garment Outline and Garment Notation pattern formats as well as with Interactive Knitting

title: Garment Notation Cheat Sheets
description: Compare the Garment Text and Garment Notation printing instructions in DAK. Explore creating a "cheat sheet" for the Garment Notation (Japanese Notation) format to make it easeer to follow the instructions as you are knitting

title: Mix 'n Match Stitch Patterns
description: Successfully combine stitch patterns in the same piece. Watch as we add a lace yoke to a sweater front and end up with the correct dimensions for the piece. Combine different gauges without wonky results

title: Russian Grafting No-Bulk Seam
description:
Here's a no-bulk seam that only eliminates the "bump" but provides a more stable seam than working Kitchener stitch. It's great for shoulder seams.
It's been called Russion Grafting ... do you know of another name for this technique?

title: Automatic Patterning 1-2-3
description: Just 3 steps to understanding Automatic Patterning, no matter what machine you use.  Punchcard or electronic, it's important to UNDERSTAND how patterning works on YOUR machine.

title: Holey Insertion
description: Eyelet technique that can be used as an insert, edge, hem or band

title: Bobbles
