description:
How to knit Bobbles on a knitting machine.
Add fun texture to your knitting with bobbles. they can stand alone but are often combined with cables and textured patterns.

How about contrasting bobbles that stand alone?
  1. Before you start knitting, create a few bobbles and remove them on stitch holders.
  2. As you are knitting, at the point where you want your bobble, use a 3 prong transfer tool and remove 3 stitches.
  3. Slip the bobble stitches behind the knitting and hang on the empty needles.
  4. Rehang the stitches from the transfer tool.
  5. Repeat across the row.

title: Thread Lace
description: Often overlooked, Thread Lace is an easy technique to create openwork "lace" fabrics. Knit with a thick yarn and a very fine yarn, there are lots of possibilities on any automatic patterning machine

title: Sideways Bust Darts
description: You don't have to increase and decrease at the edges of your knitting. Watch as we shape a bust dart in the middle of a sideways knit

title: Mini Cables with the Ribber
description: Quick 'n easy, these mini cables can add fun texture to your project

title: 'automatic' Pintucks with the Ribber
description: Combine pintucks on the ribber with stitch patterns for beautiful texture

title: Racked Lace
description: A simple needle arrangement, a bit of racking and you'll get a beautiful open-work, lace-like fabric

title: Flat Rib Zig Zag
description: Take racking to an extreme for this amazing zig-zag beauty

title: 10 Ways to Manage Floats
description: Long strands across the back of our knitting can be problematic.  Here are 10 ways to manage floats when working in color.

title: Double / Triple Decreases
description:
Full Fashion Double and Triple Decreases are a great way to add a designer touch to a shaped piece. Often used for the European Shoulder shaping. This technique is a "must have" for your knitting bag of tricks.
If you aren't familiar with Full Fashioned Decreases, please check out this video

title: Shawl Collars
description: The classic style of a shawl collar for cardigans is not hard to incorporate in your designs. Explore some examples and tips.

title: Shawl Collar Pullover
description: Shawl Collars in pullovers need a little design consideration. Explore some examples.

title: Socks in the Round
description: Knitting socks in the round eliminates a seam in the foot.  Although any ribbing must be knit flat, The foot can be knit circular.

title: Using Knit it Now Pattern Charts
description: Some knitters prefer line-by-line charted instructions for shaping. Watch how to use Knit it Now charts for neckline shaping

title: Crisp, Decorative Fold
description: 3 techniques for sharp crease when you are knitting a folded band.

title: Machine Knitters Success Path
description: Learning to machine knit is a journey. For success, take it step-by-step with Knit it Now

title: Every other Needle Knitting
description: Often knitters will use every other needle to knit a heavier yarn on a standard gauge machine. Learn the why and how of this technique

title: Moss / Seed Stitch on the Machine
description:
Moss Stitch and Seed Stitch are popular in the hand knitting world. They are highly textured and reversible. But they require hand manipulation to work on the machine.

Watch as we explore 3 ways to create Moss and Seed Stitch on the knitting machine.

Here's another way to form Seed and Moss stitch: Use a Seed Stitch Tool

title: Interchangeable Punchcard?
description: Can this punchcard be used with all stitch patterns? Examine a punchard and explore if it can be used for tuck, slip, fairisle, etc.

title: Swatching for Cables (shortcut)
description: Just like any other stitch pattern, cables impact stitch and row gauge.  For accuracy, especially for an over-all cable garment, a large swatch in the cable pattern is critical. BUT, if you are adding a single cable as an accent, explore the shortcut.

title: Puffy Stitch
description: Thick, "squishy" fabric on the standard gauge machine. Use slip to build up ridges that add bulk to this stitch pattern.

title: Hand Knit Increase
description: Often called make 1 (M1) or knit in the front and back (kfb) this is a commonly used increase for hand knitters. Learn how it's done on the machine and also watch an easier alternative.

title: Yarn for Knitting Machines
description: You don't need "special" yarn for machine knitting. Here are the facts.

title: Built-in Intarsia
description: Having the intarsia feature built-in (no extra carriage needed) is such a time saver. Watch how it's done on a manual Taitexma TH160 Mid-Gauge machine.

title: End Needle Selection: Slip
description: When knitting in slip stitch, make sure the end needles are not slipping.

title: Lace Bias
description: with a few stitch transfers create 2 beautiful, simple lace patterns.

title: Cut 'n Sew Template
description:
Using the Knit it Now Cut 'n Sew templates

Get the Template

title: Cut 'n Sew Template
description: Using the Knit it Now Cut 'n Sew Templates for beautiful neckines every time.

title: Placket Neckline Opening
description: Placket finish for Henley sweaters or kids sweaters for larger head openings

title: Decorative Sew-as-you-Go
description: Sew-as-you-go technique to add a felled, decorative seam to your knitting

title: Multiple Gauges with Dynamic patterns
description:
Most Dynamic Patterns allow you to enter the gauge for each piece in your garment. Want to knit the sleeves in a different stitch pattern than the body? No Problem!
Just enter in your gauges and let us do the math for you.

title: Toe-Up Seamless Sock
description:
Adventures in knitting in the round.
Short row toe, circular foot, afterthought hand knit heel.

title: Lace Cast-On
description: Here's a closed cast on that is stretchy and nearly invisible, perfect for lace.

title: Wavy Lace
description: Hand manipulated lacy waves. Beautiful for scarves, shawls or garments. Use as an insert for a special, lacy touch.

title: Taitexma TH160 Replace Needle
description: Replace needles and spongebar on the Taitexma TH160 knitting machine

title: Replace a Needle
description:
Replace a needle and spongebar to keep your machine in tip-top condition.

Purchase replacement needles from Knit it Now

title: Mock Cowl Neckline
description:
This is an excerpt from a recent live Knit it Now Knit Club meeting. It features a mock cowl top similar to the Astonish Top Machine Knit-able.

It is knit in a self-striping yarn and made machine-knitable.

title: Drop-Stitch Lace Part 1

Drop-Stitch Lace is an interesting technique that adds texture and interest to knitting created on the ribber. It incorporates needles on the main bed that are dropped creating lace-like holes. This is Part 1 and walks through a manual way of creating Drop-Stitch lace that will lead to understanding the technique worked on the ribber.

Part 2

Intentionally drop stitches to create "lace" on a Brother 260 bulky machine. This technique uses an accessory called a D-Slider, but it could be worked on any machine by manually dropping stitches.

title: Traditional Double Button Band
description:
Traditionally machine knitters will rehang the edge of their sweater on the machine and knit a doubled band with a turning row.
Even if the body of the sweater is knit in pattern, traditionally the bands are knit in stockinette. It is critical that you can accurately calculate the number of stitches you need to pick up.

title: Ribbed Buttonbands

title: Jaws (aka Shadow Lace Transfer Tool)
description:
The shadow lace transfer tool was originally designed to create "lace" by transferring stitches between the needlebeds.
Most knitter have adopted this tool for when they need to transfer a large number of stitches.
The tool makes the transfers so much faster than doing them one at a time with a double-eye needle.

title: Brother 'Dry Knitting'

Brother Machines: Preview a stitch pattern by "knitting" without any yarn.
The machine will pre-select needles so you can confirm the accuracy and position of the stitch pattern before even threading up the machine.

title: Plaiting on Brother Standard
description:
Knit reversible fabric. Knit 2 strands together with one showing on the knit side and the other showing on the purl side. Use the plaiting yarn feeder on Brother Standard Gauge Machines.
NOTE: this is for the Brother STANDARD gauge machiens

title: Brother: LACE Dropped Edge Stitches
description:
Do you have trouble with dropped stitches when knitting lace? Here's an un-documented tip that may help.
Also remember, lace needs weight for the stitches to form properly. Add claw weights to the edges while knitting.

title: Multi-color slip

title: Arrows Out Cable on a Knitting machine
description:
Discover how to knit the beautiful Arrows Out cable on your knitting machine! In this step-by-step demonstration, I’ll walk you through everything you need to know to create this striking design.

Perfect for adding texture and interest to your projects, the Arrows Out cable is a versatile technique that every machine knitter should have in their toolkit.

Let’s get knitting!

title: How to Knit a Proper Swatch: The Secret to Machine Knitting Success
description: Learn how to knit a proper swatch—the key to successful machine knitting! This detailed tutorial walks you through every step, from casting on to placing stitch and row markers, binding off, and recording vital details like tension and gauge. Discover tips for accurate measurements, avoiding edge distortion, and preparing your swatch for reliable results. Whether you're knitting stockinette or other stitch patterns, this guide ensures your swatches set you up for success with every project.

title: Knitting a Swatch on a Silver Reed Electronic Machine with DesignaKnit
description: Learn how to knit a swatch using a Silver Reed electronic knitting machine and DesignaKnit. This tutorial explains why gauge settings in DesignaKnit are unnecessary for swatch knitting and helps you focus on creating a successful swatch

title: Gauge Rulers

title: Your Personal Library

title: Watch this First
description:
Before you knit a sweater on your knitting machine, make sure you’re set up for success! This series walks you through the essential planning, skills, and techniques you need before starting your first sweater—so you can avoid frustration and knit something you’ll love to wear.
Sweater Success Worksheet
The Sweater Success series:
  • Watch this first
  • Plan it Right
  • Myths and Mistakes you must avoid
  • Next-level Sweaters: Master Fit and Style

title: Plan It Right: The Key to Machine Knitting a Perfect Sweater
description: Knitting a sweater on a machine isn’t just about casting on—it’s about planning for success! In this video, learn how to choose the right sweater style, pick the best yarn for your machine, and assess your skills to ensure a frustration-free knitting experience. Plus, discover how Knit It Now patterns let you knit any yarn, any machine, any gauge—no matching required!

title: Machine-Knit Sweaters: Myths & Mistakes You Must Know
description: Are you making these common sweater-knitting mistakes? Thinking the machine does all the work, skipping your swatch, or using the wrong yarn can lead to frustration and disappointment. In this video, we’re busting these myths and showing you how to set yourself up for success. At Knit It Now, swatching isn’t optional—it’s essential! Our Get Acquainted Swatch in the classroom will help you understand your machine, yarn, and tension before you cast on. Watch now and take the guesswork out of sweater knitting!" Classroom: Swatching is not Optional

title: Machine Knit Blankets
description: Want to knit a blanket on your machine but don’t know where to start? In this video, I’ll teach you how to plan your blanket from scratch—no guesswork, no limitations! Discover how to work within your machine’s needlebed size, calculate yarn needs, and use stitch patterns to create a beautiful, functional blanket.

title: Next-Level Sweaters: Master Fit, Style & Finishing
description:
Ready to level up your machine-knit sweaters? In this video, we’ll dive into advanced techniques to help you perfect the fit, add custom details, and achieve a polished finish. Plus, see how Knit It Now’s Dynamic Patterns make sweater knitting easier and more flexible than ever!

Download your Sweater Planning Worksheet here: Sweater Planning Worksheet

title: Short Row Shaping on the Knitting Machine
description: Learn how to use short row shaping (also known as partial knitting) on your knitting machine. This essential technique allows you to add curves and contours to your knitting—perfect for shoulder slopes, bust darts, necklines, sock heels, and more.
